rightsdeclaration.citation: This record is made available under a Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication Creative Commons license.

descriptivenote.p: The Congregational Library & Archives makes all bibliographic records, and the metadata contained therein, freely available to the public, and are considered to be in the Public Domain, under a Creative Commons Public Domain Designation.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday April 14, 2023 at 13:14

did.abstract: The American Congregational Association was formed in 1851 as the Congregational Library Association. The Association was formally incorporated in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in 1854. In 1864, the organization changed its name to the American Congregational Association in recognition of its broader scope. In 1857 the Association moved from its rented rooms at the Tremont Temple to a house on Chauncy Street where it remained for ten years. In 1872 the Association purchased the Somerset Building and the library moved into that space in 1874. The Association built the Congregational House in 1898 and once again the library moved into the new building. In 2017 the American Congregational Association sold the Congregational House to Faros Properties and signed a long-term lease to keep the library within its historic home. The American Congregational Association collection covers the four main areas of business of the Association: The Board of Directors, the Finances of the Association, the management of the Association's building portfolio, and the management of the Congregational Library & Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Except where otherwise stated, this collection is available for researchers only with special permission from the chair of the board or directors of the American Congregational Association and/or from the executive director of the Congregational Library & Archives. Please contact the library directly at ref@14beacon.org to obtain permission to access the collection.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the American Congregational Association records, 1846-2022, RG4360. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection is the internal permanent collection of the American Congregational Association, and by relation, the Congregational Library & Archives. Records for this collection have been gathered over the history of Library as part of the Library's records management duties. Additional records have been provided to for inclusion into the collection by board members after they have stepped down from board duties. The collection regularly receives accruals of additional materials.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Periodic accruals of records from the board or directors are expected annually. Periodic accruals of certain financial records are expected annually. Additional unplanned accruals of unspecified records are also expected.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection has been processed and organized by multiple archivists and librarians throughout the history of the American Congregational Association. The most recent version of the finding aid was produced in 2015 by Jessica Steytler according to DACS Second Edition. The collection was partially reprocessed, and fully rearranged, in 2023, by Zachary Bodnar, according to DACS 2019.0.3. The board of directors' records from 1970 to 2022 were the focus of this 2023 reprocessing, as was the integration of extant records received from former board members and from certain Library departments into the collection. Following this processing and integration, the entire arrangement of the collection was redone and the finding aid was redone. Significant reprocessing of the collection is still necessary, as is significant weeding of the collection.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The American Congregational Association was formed in 1851 as the Congregational Library Association. Two years later, reorganized and expanded, it rented rooms at the Tremont Street Temple in Boston, with a library of 56 books and pamphlets. The Association was formally incorporated in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in 1854 "for the purpose of establishing and perpetuating a library of the religious history and literature of New England, and for the erection of a suitable building for the accommodation of the same, and for the use of charitable societies." In 1864, the organization changed its name to the American Congregational Association in recognition of its broader scope.

The Association lived in peripatetic existence until 1898. In 1857 the Association moved from its rented rooms at the Tremont Temple to a house on Chauncy Street where it remained for ten years. Between 1867 and 1872, the Association again rented space before purchasing two buildings at the corner of Beacon and Somerset Streets. The building was renovated for library space and rental offices. This new headquarters was dedicated in 1874. The Association moved once more, in 1898, to its present site in the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts, a building constructed specifically for the library and for rental office space. Throughout its history, the American Congregational Association prioritized renting space to non-profit organizations.
In 2017 the American Congregational Association sold the Congregational House to Faros Properties and signed a long-term lease to keep the library within its historic home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection is the internal permanent archive of the American Congregational Association, and by relation, the Congregational Library & Archives. The collection covers the four main areas of business of the American Congregational Association: The Board of Directors, the Finances of the Association, the management of the Association's building portfolio, and the management of the Congregational Library & Archives. The collection contains minutes of meetings, important financial and tax records, committee records, records related to construction projects, architectural drawings, business proposals and reports, photographs and audio-visual materials, correspondence, management records, and records relating to the functions of the Congregational Library & Archives and its collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been divided into five series, four of which have been further divided into subseries. Four of the series are related to the four main areas of business of the American Congregational Association: The Board of Directors, the Finances of the Association, the management of the Association's building portfolio, and the management of the Congregational Library & Archives. The fifth series contains visual and audio-visual materials. Materials within each series, and the subseries themselves, have been arranged primarily by chronological order and secondarily by topic, when appropriate.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Audio-visual materials require specific equipment for playback.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the board of directors of the American Congregational Association. This series contains the meeting minutes of the board of directors as well as the various committees of the board of directors. This series also contains various governance related documents, such as by-laws and incorporation documents. Financial records may also be found within the treasurer's reports as well as within the general board records. The majority of records within this series are meeting minutes, but reports, proposals, and correspondence also make up a significant portion of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the records and minutes of meetings held by the full board of directors of the American Congregational Association. While the bulk of the materials within the subseries are minutes and departmental reports, the subseries also contains correspondence, proposals, and financial records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence from, and with, the board of directors of the American Congregational Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the governance of the American Congregational Association and its board of directors. This subseries contains mission statements, board books, by-laws, and the association's acts of incorporation.

did.unittitle: Copy of an act of incorporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the history of the American Congregational Association. Most of this subseries is related to various anniversaries of the association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to specific board members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the finance and budget committee of the American Congregational Association. The finance and budget committee was created to provide board oversight of the association's finances and budget processes. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the records of various ad-hoc committees formed for the American Congregational Association throughout its history. The bulk of the records contained within this subseries are meeting minutes.

did.unittitle: Executive committee for the fair daybook
Joint building and house committee minutes
Financial appeals task force sub-committee records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the library committee of the American Congregational Association. The library committee was created to provide board oversight the functions of the Congregational Library & Archives. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes, though presentations, proposals, and reports to the library committee are also included.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: This folder was partially created out of loose materials which were originally interleaved in the volume labeled "Library Committee minutes, 1957-1967". The original order of the contents of the folder has been maintained.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Loose materials interleaved within this volume were removed for preservation purposes and placed in the folder labeled "Library committee minutes, 1954-1967".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the records of the executive committee of the American Congregational Association. Throughout the course of its history, the executive committee handled most all matters that did not need to go before the full board. After 1998, the executive committee was disbanded and its responsibilities given the numerous, more focused, board committees, to further empower the full board. Many 20th century decisions made by the American Congregational Association can be traced to decisions made by the executive committee. The bulk of the materials in this subseries are meeting minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the investment committee of the American Congregational Association. The investment committee was created to provide board oversight of the investment accounts of the American Congregational Association. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes, though financial and investment records are also a part of the investment committee records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains reports made by the treasurer of the American Congregational Association to the board of directors. The bulk of the materials within this subseries are quarterly financial reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the personnel committee of the American Congregational Association. The personnel committee was created to provide board oversight of the employees of the American Congregational Association. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes, though presentations, proposals, and reports to the personnel committee are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the board development committee of the American Congregational Association. The board development committee, also sometimes called the nominating committee, was created to recommend new members for the board. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes and communications between board members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the development committee of the American Congregational Association. The development committee has had different names throughout its history including the advancement committee, the financial development committee, and the finance development committee. The development committee was created to provide board oversight of the associations fundraising efforts. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes, though presentations, proposals, and reports to the development committee are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the program committee of the American Congregational Association. The program committee was created to provide board oversight of the Library's public programming. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records created by, and for, the building committee of the American Congregational Association. The building committee was created to provide board oversight of the management and functions of the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts. The bulk of the records are meeting minutes, though presentations, proposals, and reports to the building committee are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the finances of the American Congregational Association. The bulk of the series contains correspondence and ledgers kept by the treasurers of the American Congregational Association. This series also contains records related to membership and pledge drives that were intended to raise money for the association. This series also contains records related to taxes paid and owed by the American Congregational Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains financial records related to the functions of the American Congregational Association. Most of the account books within this series were kept by the various treasurers of the American Congregational Association. This subseries also contains some records of receipts and disbursements. Financial records more specifically related to the buildings owned by the American Congregational Association and to the Congregational Library & Archives may be found in their respective series.

did.unittitle: Comparative statements of income and expenditures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records which are related to membership programs or subscription drives; both are activities that the American Congregational Association has undertaken to raise funds during the course of its history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence related to the finances of the Congregational American Association at large. The bulk of the correspondence is related to William Cobb and Ralph Whitney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to federal, state, and city taxes. Most of the records are related to audited financial records and form 990s but this series also contains records related to tax statuses, tax abatements, and retirement accounts.

did.unittitle: Tax abatements and real estate taxes
Return of property held for charitable purposes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the construction, management, maintenance, and history of the buildings owned by the American Congregational Association. The majority of the records within this series relate to the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts, whose construction was completed in 1898, though some of the earliest records relate to the Somerset Building, which housed the Congregational Library before it was moved to the Congregational House in 1898. This series contains correspondence, reports, deeds and quitclaim deeds, financial records, rent books, assessments, construction documents, legal proceedings, and architectural drawings. This series also contains records directly related to the American Congregational Association's decisions on whether to sell the building at various times during the association's history. Records related specifically to the facilities of the library may be found in the series, "Congregational Library & Archives records, 1853-2022."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains financial and legal records related to the American Congregational Association's ownership of properties such as the Somerset Building and the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts. This subseries contains deeds and quitclaim deeds, ledgers, and records relating to financing and capital funding.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains reports, assessments, and other memos related to the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts as well as the Somerset Building. Most of the records within this collection are related to the physical status of the building and many are related to assessments taken prior to construction or renovation projects.

did.unittitle: Massachusetts Historical Commission restoration grant final report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the history of the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts, as well as the Somerset Building. This series contains articles, newspaper clippings, anniversary programs, and records related to the Kansas City statement of faith plaque that adorns the Congregational House's front entrance.

did.unittitle: Kansas City statement of faith 50th anniversary records
National Register of Historic Places documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains general correspondence about the buildings variously controlled by the American Congregational Association including the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts, and the Somerset building. A majority of the correspondence in this subseries is related to Frank D. Bradley.

did.unittitle: Frank D. Bradley correspondence, Otis Elevator Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the tenants of the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts. The majority of the records within this subseries are related to the collection of rents, though the subseries also contains records related to disputes with tenants, such as legal actions taken against some tenants.

did.unittitle: Legal actions against National Society of Puritan Decendants

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains architectural drawings for the Congregational House, both exterior and interior, at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the management of the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts. Especially prevalent within this subseries are records related to 3rd party vendors the American Congregational Association contracted with to handle the management of the building.

did.unittitle: Charge of corruption against building superintendent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to various construction and renovation projects the American Congregational Association undertook to maintain and expand the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts. This subseries contains correspondence, reports, contractor proposals, and supporting documentation and specifications for various construction projects. This series also contains records related to preservation agreements for the building with the state of Massachusetts. Records related specifically to renovations and construction projects within the Congregational Library's space, rather than the building at large, may be found in the subseries, "Facilities, 1963-2020," under the series, "Congregational Library & Archives records, 1853-2022."

did.unittitle: Library and building enhancement project plan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related the possible, or actual, sale of the Congregational House at 14 Beacon Street, Boston, Massachusetts. The American Congregational Association long grappled with the idea of selling the building. The association nearly sold the building in 2008 but an economic downturn resulted in the buyer pulling out from the deal. The Congregational House was sold to Faros Properties in 2017. This sub-series contains records related to discussions had regarding the sale of the building, information and resources created in the lead up to potential sales of the building, and correspondence and communications from the board of directors about the sale of the building, and the lease the association signed with Faros Properties in the wake of the sale of the building.

did.unittitle: Legal correspondence related to building sale
Special mailings for sale of building

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the Congregational Library & Archives and its various functions such as external communications, fundraising, and the administration and everyday functions of the Library itself. This series also contains records about the collections held by the Library as well as some records related to the Congregational Christian Historical Society. The Congregational Library & Archives has always been the primary function of the American Congregational Association's work, and after the sale of the Congregational House in 2017, became the sole focus of the ACA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence related to the Congregational Library & Archives, especially correspondence from former librarians, such as Isaac Langworthy and Hal Worthley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the administration and everyday functions of the Congregational Library & Archives. This subseries contains policy documents, records related to former librarians, especially Isaac Langworthy and Hal Worthley, library account books, and select records about former staff.

did.unittitle: Wages and staff shortages related to World War II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the Congregational Library and Archives's efforts to raise money through donations, bequests, and gifts. Included within this subseries are records related to gifts, bequests, special funds, and fundraising communications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the Congregational Library & Archives's external communications efforts. This subseries contains brochures and pamphlets about the Library, leaflets for programs, publicity publications, and correspondence related to the Bulletin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records about the print and manuscript collections held by the Congregational Library & Archives. This subseries contains collection inventories, appraisals, notes about portions of the collections, records relating to the loan of the Johnathan Mayhew portrait to the National Gallery, condition surveys, and records relating to specific collecting projects. Of special import in this subseries is the 1853 book list which contains a list of the first 56 books that were donated to the Congregational Library.

did.unittitle: Catalog of books belonging to the Congregational Library Association

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: This subseries is restricted and not available to library users. This restriction is not expected to expire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to reference requests and correspondence with researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records related to the Congregational Christian Historical Society (CCHS). The Society was founded by Frederick L. Fagley and following his death the society moved to the Congregational House. Over time, the functions of the CCHS were absorbed into the Congregational Library & Archives. By the 21st century, the executive director of the CCHS was also the executive director of the Library and by 2008 the CCHS, and its mission, was formally merged into the Library. This subseries contains some few records related to the history of the CCHS, as well as records related to the merger of the CCHS into the Congregational Library & Archives.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Congregational Library & Archives maintains the archive of the Congregational Christian Historical Society. The collection, titled "Congregational Christian Historical Society records, 1899-2010" (RG1187) is available to researchers interested in the history of the organization upon request. More information about the collection, as well as a link to the collection's finding aid, may be found in the collection's catalog record.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records directly related to the physical facilities of the Congregational Library & Archive. Most of this series contains records related to construction and renovation projects solely devoted to the expansion, maintenance, or improvement of the Library's facilities. Of particular note are records related to the construction of the Rare Book Room, the construction of the Library's award-winning HVAC system, and the renovation and expansion of the Library's offices in the wake of the American Congregational Association's sale of the Congregational House.

did.unittitle: Renovation project programming, planning, design proposal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographic and audio-visual materials about the Congregational Library & Archives and the American Congregational Association. The photographs include images of the Congregational House, both exterior and interior, images of Congregationalists, images of building and library staff, as well as images of events. The audio-visual materials include interviews, such as an interview production with Hal Worthley, images on CDs, and materials related to programs and events related to the library and association.

did.unittitle: Dedication of the Rare Book Room
